text:
Hello, I'm a new comer to Julia, and I was going through the Docs and I saw that the same function is defined twice, once as a method and once as a function.
This is the first time I have encountered something like this. Could someone please explain why is this convention followed and what is the difference between the two?
PS: I apologize if I am not messaging in the right channel :sweat_smile:

text: You always define methods. Can you link the relevant section you are talking about?

elements.text: You always define methods. Can you link the relevant section you are talking about?

text: Usually, people define a function without a method in order to add a single docstring, one single place

elements.text: Usually, people define a function without a method in order to add a single docstring, one single place

text: <@U67SCG4HG> Here, this is what i meant by it. The base.get function/method has two definitions, which essentialy seem to have the same content

elements.text: Here, this is what i meant by it. The base.get function/method has two definitions, which essentialy seem to have the same content

text: What do you mean with same content? They have different signatures

elements.text: What do you mean with same content? They have different signatures

text: Hi Amogh, so the way I think about it is that in Julia, a _function_ is an abstract thing while a methods are particular instantiations of that thing. A function refers to just a name, while a method refers to the actual signature/parameters. So say you define `foo()`, `foo(a::Int)`and `foo(a::Int, b::Float64)` . Then I'll say there is a _function_ called `foo` , which has three methods. If you only define `bar(x::String)`, then I'll say there is a function `bar` with only one method.

elements.text: Hi Amogh, so the way I think about it is that in Julia, a
function
is an abstract thing while a methods are particular instantiations of that thing. A function refers to just a name, while a method refers to the actual signature/parameters. So say you define
foo()
foo(a::Int)
and
foo(a::Int, b::Float64)
. Then I'll say there is a
function
called
foo
, which has three methods. If you only define
bar(x::String)
, then I'll say there is a function
bar
with only one method.

text: There are probably some more nuances, but this is how I think about functions and methods.

elements.text: There are probably some more nuances, but this is how I think about functions and methods.

text:
Oh I see the confusion, it isn't quite captured in that screenshot though: <https://docs.julialang.org/en/v1/base/collections/#Base.get-Tuple{Any,Any,Any}>

There's a listing for both Base.get as a method separately, and then also as a function with two methods. Perhaps this is an issue with the organization of the documentation? And then why does get! have two separate method entries but no function entry? Maybe "method" entries should always be grouped inside a "function" entry.
